Barash, D. P. 1989. Marmots:social behavior and ecology. Stanford Univ. Press, Stanford, California. xvii + 360 pp.

NatureServe. 2014. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://explorer.natureserve.org. (Accessed: February 21, 2014 ).
habitat_description:
The Yellow-bellied Marmot (Marmota caligata) inhabits ecosystems ranging from rocky, xeric parts of low deserts in Oregon and Washington to lush subalpine and alpine high meadows in the Sierra Nevadas and southern Rocky Mountains, including riparian cottonwood groves, alpine tundra and foothills canyons (Barash 1989, NatureServe 2014).   They tend to avoid dense forest, swamps, and marshes, but will use open, grassy or forb dominated forests.
Towards the southern portion of their range, they inhabit montane ‘islands’, such as Sangre de Cristo Mountains, NM.  Zeiner et al. (2008) listed alpine dwarf-shrub, perennial grassland, wet meadows, subalpine conifer, and open stands of lodgepole pine forest as optimal habitat and open, grassy understories of mixed conifer, montane riparian, red fir, eastside pine, montane chaparral, sagebrush, bitterbrush, low sage, aspen, Jeffrey pine, and pinyon-juniper as other suitable habitats in California.
Hoary and Yellow-bellied Marmots appear to displace one another in areas of where their ranges overlap (e.g., Purcell and Flint Creek Ranges in Montana); Yellow-bellied Marmots occupy lower elevations while Hoary Marmots occupy high elevations.  In parts of northern Wyoming and southern Montana, Hoary Marmots are absent at the higher elevation sites and they are therefore occupied by Yellow-bellied Marmots. N. Tarr, 4April2014.
